Inside Out continues Pixar's remarkable streak of combining heart and soul with equal measures of fun and playfulness to create arguably their most profound film to date.Like the many wonderful films that came before this, Pixar have instilled a great deal of passion and warmth into their creation. The execution of what is really in many ways such a simple premise, but in such an inventive and unique way, is the key to the genius of the film, as both a colourful kids movie, but also something a lot deeper that the more mature audiences members can appreciate and understand as well.On paper, Inside Out certainly may seem to come across as too smart for what should be a simple kids movie. Yet those Disney hallmarks are there to hold your hand; the colourful characters, delightful voice work from the talented cast and typical Disney charm, all remind you that despite some weighty themes and certain heartbreaking moments, Inside Out can still be the fun Disney escapism that you want it to be.

Inside Out almost had me in tears. I am someone who, generally speaking, practically never cries or swells up in movies. When I do, that means the film is something truly special. Either that or I'm becoming really sentimental. *sighAnd, yet, there is so, so, so much to commend this film for. And, not sure about you, but I'm beginning to think that Pete Docter is the best, most imaginative person working at pixar today. Every single one of his films have been masterpieces. Inside Out is no exception. I've always admired pixar for tackling themes that, even by Disney's standards, are complex in a family. Here they tackle them literally head first. I would also attain that Inside Out is easily pixars funniest film, with Sadness' meloncholy and the differences with people's emotions being the highlights of the film.Joy is also brilliant, as her journey through Riley's mind allows her to grow as a character, as well as Riley herself. Her relationship with Sadness is another sheer highlight.Fear, Disgust and Anger provide plenty of great moments, as does Riley's imaginary friend, Bing Bong. What's really spectacular about this film is the world building; the characters, the settings, the situations.I'll be honest: I cannot find a flaw in Inside Out. Not to say that it doesn't have them, only that they are really so insignificant given the broader creativity and sheer ingenuity that everyone involved brings to the picture.

Inside Out is a fantastic film which is one of if not the the best film Pixar has ever made. It tells the story of a 11-year-old girl named Riley who's life turns to chaos as her family moves to San Francisco, and the story is told through the prospective of her emotions personified as characters. Joy, played by Amy Poehler, Sadness, played by Phyllis Smith, Anger, played by Lewis Black, Disgust, played by Mindy Kaling and Fear, played by Bill Hader.Inside Out is fantastic because there seems to be several stories told at the same time. The first is the story of Riley's new life in San Francisco, and the story of the ark that the emotions go through, but when you look at this film in a deeper way, Inside Out is a psychological metaphor for growing up as there are many elements inside of Riley's head that reflects the psychology of our actual brains. Elements such as forgetting, train of thought, long-term memory, subconscious, abstract thought and other things. The movie also takes a serious but not overly dark look on grief, as Joy (Riley's main and most important emotion) has to deal with Sadness. The psychology and metaphors in this movie makes Inside Out extremely clever. If a parent was to see this movie with their kids, the parent and the kids would have very different experiences. The character ark are also well done with the lessons the emotions and Riley has to learn. The movie isn't just excellent with its writing, but its also great as entertainment. The movie is a roller coaster of emotions as there will be scenes you'll be bursting out in laughter and other scenes where you'll be bawling your eyes out. The movie tugs on your emotion and is quite a tear jerker but is evenly split out by being thoroughly funny. The performances by this film's flawless cast are hilarious and uses legit humour about emotions and the mind instead of just pandering to kids. The animation is also gorgeous to look at and is a must own on Blu-ray. There's absolutely no flaws I can give this film. It's personally my favourite film of all time and it's an instant classic. It is highly recommended that if if haven't seen this film than you should see it immediately.I give Inside Out an A+

Nine writers are credited on IMDb including a couple of the cast members for improvisational material, but Pete Docter and Ronnie Del Carmen keep this Pixar film on track. Pixar succeeds again with a story that both kids and adults can enjoy. The five personified emotions in Riley's head speak a lot of truth. The movie seems to get a lot right psychologically when it comes to memory and childhood development. The bright colors, adventure plot, and deep pathos puts this over the top! Amy Poehler, Phyllis Smith, Bill Hader, Lewis Black, and Mindy Kaling are a great ensemble at the brain control center. Richard Kind as Bing Bong, Riley's fun loving imaginary friend, is the heart of the picture. It was an especially smart move to focus on Poehler as Joy and Smith as Sadness as an exploration of what it means to mature. I love that Dave Goelz and Frank Oz of Muppets fame have voice cameos in the subconscious. Cinematic memories and dreams make for an intelligent flick about growing up.

Pixar have created some of the best animations that can spring to many a persons mind, Inside Out is an addition that is just as excellent as you might hope it to be. The way in which this movie mixes not just fun but emotion and how we deal with it well it makes this much more profound and adds a lot of meaning. The movie basically is all about Riley, or to be way more specific inside Riley's head with all her emotions being little well, who knows actually, they are just emotions with bodies. Of course the movie isn't all just in Riley's head, we see Riley act out the emotions she feels and how it affects her new life as her and her family start a new life in San Francisco. The movie is crafted how animation should be with vivid colours and great detail, but add to that a sweet story in the middle and you have one absolutely fantastic little film.After the hugely popular "Up" in 2009, Pete Docter directs and co-writes a Pixar animation yet again and does a very good job making this look absolutely beautiful. The animation is also in fantastic detail in regards to that this movie is all made up mostly architecture wise with it being majority within Riley's head which contains a mind HQ, A vast array of memories stored and thrown away and even a dream production company who decide what Riley will be dreaming about that night. The film is massive in its scale and yet set in such a small space really; the people behind this really have used imagination to an extent that this must be one of the best thought out animations ever. With the emotions come voice cast like Amy Poehler (Joy), Phyllis Smith (Sadness), Bill Hader (Fear), Mindy Kaling (Disgust) and Lewis Black as Anger who really feels like he is about to swear at any moment he is on screen. The characters are fun but the voice cast are game too and really create a great sense of well character, I loved Poehler as Joy who is basically the main character of this movie but really all the little emotions and all the things living within Riley's mind are great fun and really well thought up. The film has as said a meaning to it, more than just big jumps and rolls and a fun little adventure, sure it has that but it also deals with basically depression which then goes on to show that it can strike anyone of any age however happy they may seem to be. The film of course is no psychoanalysis studies piece but it is on the surface a film that breaks down barriers where really the main character is not always a happy one and does suffer. I really have to applaud the movie for exploring such things which really aren't what you might expect from an animated movie which is let's face it directed toward the kids in society but it does it in a way where anyone of any age can feel for the movie and also find it fantastic.So Inside Out, an animated film that really is something a little special and something I found hard not to love just a little. It also I think can show that not all grown ups are ever fully out of there childhood, this is so fun it is hard not to watch it a little like being a child again and although the young one's will enjoy this, the adults should too. Pixar have yet again created something super fun and actually really important, hats off to the studio for really bringing something new to the animation game and showing that there is plenty of life left in Pixar.

Incredibly inventive, brilliantly written, wonderfully animated and powerfully moving, Inside Out is the best and the most original delivery of Pixar since Wall-E. A perfectly working formula of laughs, adventures, original ideas, dazzling visuals and family-friendly entertainment, this animation is the clear and obvious favorite for Best Animated Feature for 2015. A concept that would hardly be repeated, the idea of depicting the human brain as a bunch of funny, little, hyper-active creatures called emotions would stay stuck with you for a long time after seeing the movie. Simply because you would be asking yourself, how did the Pixar screenwriters come with it. A story of a young girl and how she copes with her first teen years and her family relocating to San Francisco, Pete Docter and Ronnie Del Carmen's movie offer a most curious take on Riley's ( voiced by Kaitlyn Dias) coming-of-age. A take that is compelling to both major types of audiences, kids and adults and that has the power to entertain equally both parties. Inside Out is an animation which could not just be reviewed or described, as it offers a wonderful and personal experience for everyone who sees t. A must see, this is already an instant classic and could most deservedly be placed among the Top 5 Pixar deliveries ever.
Another great film from the best animation studio in the world. Pixar have produced a funny, heart warming film with a cracking promise that one can only hope they visit again in the years to come.

Inside Out is a fantastic, entertaining and emotional roller coaster!!! More suited for adults rather than children, it illustrates its' plot in a way that could easily represent an adult's emotions as well. The stunning visuals that are displayed in the mind of the main character are a new pinnacle for Pixar. The story of Riley and her developing emotions as she grows from infant to early teenager is a clever exercise in human behavioral development. The emotion, Joy, is the main emotion in charge, but is accompanied by Disgust, Sadness, Anger and Fear. When Riley is uprooted from her home in Minnesota to San Francisco, her suppressed sadness sends her emotions and life into a tail spin. I won't give away any more and recommend that you see the movie for yourself. Pixar has long been a high quality powerhouse when it comes to great stories, characters and digital art. "Inside Out" has set a new bar for them. Being their longest developed movie thus far, you can tell that they put a lot of thought into it. It is definitely worth a view!

UPDATED 04/09/15There's a reason why this film is the second best reviewed film of the summer (only behind Shaun the Sheep, which opened much later in America).The film is about an 11-year-old girl and hockey fan named Riley Andersen (yes, it's spelled with an 'en', not an 'on') whose family moves from Minnesota to San Francisco after her father Bill has a new job there. There are five feelings in each of everyone's heads; Joy, Sadness, Fear, Disgust and Anger, but the main crux of the story is the feelings in Riley's head. On Riley's first day of school in San Francisco, a malfunction in Riley's Emotions' Headquarters (where all the five feelings reside) causes Joy and Sadness to be separated from there when the former unsuccessfully tries to stop Sadness from creating a sad memory, leaving the other three feelings to make Riley have difficulties coping with her new life. Will Joy and Sadness make it back to the Headquarters before things go from bad to worse?This is a movie many people, both children and adults can relate to; balancing the effects of joy and sadness, the latter which can make things good or bad, as evidenced in the movie. Children will enjoy the animated characters, and adults will enjoy the concept of the movie of how the feelings can make Riley do certain actions, and how the absence of sadness and happiness eventually lead to her 'Personality Islands' (Family, Honesty, Friendship, Hockey and Goofball) crumble and land up in the Memory Dump below. And if you think Riley's mind couldn't be more complicated there's also Imagination Land, Dream Productions and Subconscious, where Riley's deepest fears are in, which includes a clown.It also helps that the film was thoroughly engaging, and there were some jokes to balance the heavy themes of the movie (for example, see the scene on Abstract Thought, where Joy, Sadness and an imaginary character named Bing Bong were gradually 'deconstructed into geometrical shapes' until they left the area). I was close to crying twice in the movie; in the beginning and the climatic ending.It's quite hard for an animated film to be one of the best of the year, but this film manages to do so, and it will easily be my no.1 film of 2015, if not the no. 2 film. After all, it's also an important lesson that life is not just about happiness; some sadness needs to be present too.I'm going to give this a strong 9/10 and definitely a recommendation. I could give this a 10/10, but this was so close to achieving that feat.Well done once again, Pete Docter. Keep it up.The voice cast in the movie includes Amy Poehler, Mindy Kaling and Phyllis Smith (who voice 3 of the emotions in Riley's head), and as with most Disney animated films, is preceded by a short film if you watch the movie in a theatre. The short film here is called "Lava".Pros:Very innovative storyGreat animationEnjoyable charactersHeartwarming ending (you'll probably cry)Cons:Very minor and can be easily forgiven.

WARNING: contains spoiler. This movie was outstanding. First off, let's just say that this movie is very unique. Featuring all the feelings was very creative of Pixar, and the crux of the whole film. Next, because they featured the emotions within Riley's mind, the development was unusually heavy and deep. You know why they brag that this movie is made by the guys who made UP? Because the Up guys really put their hearts into it. That 10 minute relationship between Carl and his wife? Here, it's turned into a full-feature child-parents relationship, but also with Riley and her relationship with the new area she moves to.Of course, uniqueness and development are only the tip of the ice berg. The movie is tension-filled, leaving me on my edge of my seat, tearing my hair out, yelling: "Nooooo! NOOOOOOOO!!!" (Especially near the climax scene where the emotions narrowly don't make it!) The fact that it's realistic and the lands Joy and Sadness travel to fall down one-by-one, showing that Riley is losing her core self and losing who she truly is--becoming a robot, becoming out of touch with her emotions--oh dang; that's truly suspenseful and horrifying! And shall I mention (BIG spoiler--You are warned here and now--BIG spoiler)-- Bing Bong sacrifices himself in order to make Riley happy--but it's not just about Joy. No; it's not about Joy leading onwards, optimistic no matter what. It shows that people have duality of emotions. It's realistic- - and the multitude of emotions, instead of simply one emotion (or no emotion at all in the case of the movie's crucial pinpoint), there are a load of emotions within the movie.Obviously, this movie is not just deep and touching. Let us end this review on a lighter note--this movie has excellent comedy as well. The main comical subject is the aforementioned Bing Bong in my opinion), which makes his "death" ever so-more heart-wrenching. But other than that, the humor is quite intelligent. The helicopter guy ("come with me, La Chi-na."), Tripledent Gum, Angry's flame, goofball land, they all add a good amount of laughs and heart-warming moments to this film. So in conclusion, this movie is amazing. It's one of pixar's best, if not the best-- failing only second arguably to the Toy Story series. (And even that is arguable). If you haven't watched it, you definitely should. It has made it into the top ten of my best movies ever watched. :D

Pixar's first full-fledged movie for grown ups. Ok, maybe that's not entirely true, but I can't see how a child would find this interesting. Sure there are bright colors and cute little avatars for emotions, but everything about this movie is designed to make parents sob and have all of the feels all at once. I'm speaking from experience here, because Jenny and I couldn't go 20 minutes without tears streaming down our faces at the thought of our own daughter growing up and going through all of these complex emotions. The moral of the story, which has so much depth and complexity and humor, seems to be this: NEVER UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES MOVE YOUR CHILD ACROSS THE COUNTRY. There's also a Chinatown reference that made me cry tears of laughter. Still, this feels less like a film and more like a fascinating experiment.

I feel like I say this all the time with Pixar movies, but this one is something special. "Inside Out" is one of those movies that is truly unique. How many times have you heard the expression, "Do you ever wonder what's going on in that person's head?" Well, "Inside Out" gives a potential answer to that question by showing a person's emotions as living entities, all of whom reside in the person's head. Riley is an 11-year-old girl whose family is moving from Minnesota to California. As you might expect, she has mixed emotions about it. We see those emotions interacting with each other inside Riley's mind. There's the ever-chipper Joy (voiced by Amy Poehler), the despondent Sadness (voiced by Phyllis Smith), the red-hot Anger (voiced by Lewis Black), the fidgety Fear (voiced by Bill Hader), and the snide and sarcastic Disgust (voiced by Mindy Kaling). Depending on how Riley is feeling at that particular moment, that emotion will be "driving" inside Riley's mind. It's an interesting concept, but the movie goes even further, showing how memories are made and how they get stashed in a sort of internal vault. The mind houses different aspects of Riley's personality, like Imagination Land, Goofball Land, and Hockey Land. There's a "Train of Thought" that constantly runs back and forth between Riley's mind (dubbed "Headquarters" by the emotions) and the different lands. The mind can summon up a memory from the vault if Riley is attempting to recall something (though that will occasionally result in a catchy jingle from a chewing gum commercial, one of those grating tunes that, try as you might, you just can't get it out of your head). And this is all just the set-up. I don't want to get into too many details, as part of the pleasure is watching it all unfold for yourself. There is no shortage of imagination on display during the course of "Inside Out," particularly when a few of the emotions begin plumbing the depths of Riley's mind. In typical Pixar fashion, the animation and visuals are stunning; the colors are bright and effervescent, and there are more than a few witty visual jokes. Also in typical Pixar fashion, the movie serves up an important lesson to kids (and maybe even adults, for that matter) without pandering to them. In this instance, "Inside Out" is letting children know that it's OK to be sad, something the emotions learn as well. Ideally, the emotions would like Joy to be in control the majority of the time, as it means that Riley is happy. But one of the more difficult facts of life to accept is that without sadness (or Sadness), there can be no joy (or Joy). The two are kind of dependent on each other. It's OK for happy memories to be tinged with a little bit of melancholia, and vice versa. The two complement each other. There's no shortage of poignancy in "Inside Out" either, and just like its other Pixar brethren, it earns these moments. They never feel forced or obligatory. One of the more painful aspects of growing up is leaving certain thoughts and memories behind, like an imaginary friend, for example. Once a child starts making actual friends, the imaginary ones tend to get buried deep within the subconscious before being forgotten completely. "Inside Out" visualizes this process, and it's hard not to be moved. Seriously, in how many other movies can you think of in which you felt involved in the plight of an imaginary elephant-cat creature? At this point in time, there's really no point of ranking the Pixar movies as each product they turn out continues to be quality. I will say that "Inside Out" offered one of the most original premises I've seen in years, be it Pixar movie or any movie in general. And the company continues to demonstrate that, as long they're around, it will not be a chore for parents to take their kids to movies. I know this much: if there really are little emotions commingling inside my head, it was definitely Joy who was in control while watching this movie.

When I first saw the pics for this movie I thought it was about little living emojis/emoticons, it does look like that doesn't it? Nope, instead its actually about little living creatures inside your head that represent emotions. When I say living creatures I'm not so sure that's even correct, they are more like representations of the mind or emotions, each one a little physical embodiment of each emotion. Its not an overly original concept lets be totally honest, I know I've seen this type of thing before in cartoons many times, and in pretty similar fashion, but again lets be honest, there's only a few ways you can do this.So the plot revolves around a little girl as she is born, and at the same time her little emotions are born within her head (I assume). We follow little Riley as she grows up with her parents and experiences all of life's wonder and beauty, but of course, all of the little negative bits too. At the same time we see everything from inside little Riley's head from the perspective of her emotions and how they each deal with individual situations. Naturally each emotion deals with different things such as sadness, anger, joy etc...they each specialise in their emotion of course. Alas, many years later aged 11, one day goes tits up when Riley attends her first day at school and loses control, she begins to cry because she is home sick, this causes a permanent negative memory which Joy (the happy emotion) tries to get rid of. In a series of bizarre accidents Joy and Sadness get ejected from the control room (the brain) and end up lose within Riley's head. Without Joy in Riley's mind (and life) keeping control, the duo now have to get back into Riley's brain/mind before she becomes depressed forever, seemingly.Right so the emotions, a generic bunch truth be told, Anger, Joy, Sadness, Disgust and Fear. Anger is a little red fellow that isn't a million miles away from a satanic looking creation, he also emits fire when in a rage. He is probably the second best emotion going for obvious reason really, one of the funniest emotions. Joy is the main protagonist and is a happy-go-lucky shiny female character that is rather vomit inducing. Sadness is probably the best emotion if you ask me, he looks kinda plain yet random in design, but his permanent, nervous, hyper paranoid persona is clearly the main laugh out loud machine. Disgust is easily the weakest of the bunch with not much to do or say frankly. She is modelled on young teenage valley girls which is a good notion, but highly annoying (check her glittery appearance). Lastly we have Sadness who is a stereotypically short, plump, glasses wearing female character that kinda reminds you of the nerdy high school girl, the librarians assistant type. She mopes around being all glum and useless, again, kinda annoying and makes you wonder why no one ever kills her.Overall the emotions are a reasonably fun little group but nothing overly hilarious, personally I found the other background characters much more interesting. The best of these has to be Bing Bong who was Riley's old childhood imaginary friend, but long forgotten. This guy is a combination of Riley's favourite things from that young age, his body is made of candy floss and various animal parts...plus he cries candy. His sidekick is an old child's tow wagon with rocket boosters that fire a rainbow coloured discharge, this was Riley's old toy back in the day which she would play and imagine could fly like a space rocket. This guy gives us some of the best laughs throughout the main adventure through Riley's mind, but he also gives us some of the most emotional. I don't think I can deny that I almost cried when he meets his end. Hands up who's with me here...yeah, I thought so. The various other colourful, bizarre, weird and wonderful little mind creatures we meet along the way are all really well designed and voiced acted, like I said, overall I think the majority were actually more engaging than the main characters. I really didn't like the designs for the main emotions, they just seemed way too simplistic and generic.I also have to say I didn't like or understand the other emotional representatives in other peoples minds, they didn't really make sense. Hear me out, Riley's mind emotions don't look anything like her, they are just visual representations of the emotion. Now when we go to Riley's dad (who has a tash), his mind emotions also have little moustaches, Riley's mum has emotions that look like her with the glasses and hair. Then in the end credits we see more mind emotions for other people, all of them look like the people they inhabit. One guy who works as a clown even has mind emotions that look like clowns, eh?? why would his mind emotions look like clowns when that's just his day job? So I guess the question is, why does Riley have random looking emotions when everyone else has emotions that look like them? Yeah I know this is a kids flick and I'm [b]really[/b] looking too far into this, but things like that kinda bug me cause it doesn't really add up. The animal ones really seemed far fetched as the emotions just run wild inside the animals head, so I guess that would work? who knows.The visuals are of course stunning, really slick, but did you expect anything less? really? I'm not trying to take anything away from the visuals but these days its really no big deal anymore is it, if a movie looks less than stunning then its something to talk about. I did like the imagination on display though, some really great ideas fleshed out, not all great, I would have done some things differently, but still good. I really liked the abyss of lost memories or memory dump, nice touch. The individual floating personality islands were neat, like family island or friendship island, that house memories of those certain aspects in Riley's life. I liked how they fell apart when affected by Riley's emotional state being rocked badly. I also liked the train of thought which was of course...a train. Overall the ideas and some visuals reminded me of an old animated movie called 'The Phantom Tollbooth', which also delved into such things as individual human traits being fleshed out, alongside things like words and numbers.Its a strong emotional ride that's for sure, no puns intended. The kids will love the visuals and the wacky characters, whilst the adults will enjoy the trip down memory lane for the...errmm, the childhood memory aspect of it all. I'm sure many people will be able to relate to what's going on, first day of school and crying, snow days, moving etc...its all there, the full gamut of human anguish and joy. The way they have thought out how things like memories, long term memories, forgotten memories, special memories etc...all work is very clever, typically adults make everything into a bureaucratic headache, but it works well. But like I said already I didn't really feel the main emotions, which was a problem, they weren't overly funny but slightly annoying. I mean come on, Sadness creates all the problems, everything is her fault! and she kept on touching everything and fucking it up!! arrgghhh!! Still I can't deny this was an excellent little rollercoaster that had me on the edge of my seat wondering how they would ever save the day.

Here's this movie in a nutshell: A young girl gets sad and upset cuz she and her parents had to move to San Francisco. And then she decides San Francisco isn't all that bad.That's it. That's the movie. And the story is told thru some cute characters who represent the girl's different emotions (Sadness, Joy, etc.) Sometimes I wonder if I watched a different version of the movie than the rest of those who stumble over themselves to heap praise on it. That's certainly the case here. Sometimes animated feature films are written to appeal to 8 year olds, and other times they are written to appeal to a wider audience, including adults. In this case it was written solely for 8 year olds. She attends a new school and has to stand in front of the class and tell them about herself. So, you guessed it, Fear takes over as she stands up, then Joy tries to overcome and get her excited to talk to the class, then she sees the kids staring and gets fearful, and so on. That's the movie. You watch the emotion characters inside her brain dealing with events in her life as she moves to a new city. Now I suppose if you really enjoy the cute little emotion characters then the movie is okay. But otherwise there's nothing here. No story, no tension, no really funny moments. And the characters are the definition of predictable. Geez, let me see...what will "Sadness" say? Hmmm...I could only stand 1/2 hour and ended it. Terrible. UPDATE: I forced myself to watch the entire thing. Yeah, it sucked. Joy and Sadness spend most of the movie trying to get back to "headquarters", and in the end Riley decides San Francisco isn't all that bad. Yeah, this sucked.

After some sequels and the the somewhat average "Brave," Pixar returns to top form with an original film that is unique, creative, completely fresh, and filled with tons of humor and heart...and as a parent it utterly destroyed me emotionally. I think it's safe to say that we can title this film as one of Pixar's classics, as this was one of the best animations I've seen in years. Inside Out has an extremely unique plot, along with some gorgeous animation and a clever script, and like I said, will probably be remembered as one of Pixar's best films to date. The voice actors in this movie did a great job of bringing out the personality of each and every emotion, and the animators were just as talented when they were tasked with bringing these characters to life on the big screen. This is genuinely a movie where kids can enjoy the adventure, teens can relate to, and adults can love. This movie pretty much relates to anyone who's ever been alive, and is one that can probably leave many in tears after watching this film. For those critics that gave this movie a rotten rating, I'm not sure how that occurred, but either way, this movie was awesome. What I really loved about this movie was the emotions. Obviously, they're the biggest part of this movie, but I really loved watching these emotions interact with each other. This movie even goes beyond the mind of one person and lets us see into the minds of everyone around us. It's also awesome how the director and writers were able to make each emotion clearly stand out. They all have their own personality and their scripts were made just for them. Honestly, Anger was my favorite because he gave a perfect amount of comedy along with the funniest lines in the movie. Fear and Disgust also added a lot the movie, and I probably liked Anger and Fear the most. Joy was also really good as the lead, and Sadness wasn't all impressive to me, but I enjoyed all the characters none the less. An animation is nothing unless the voice actors can bring the script to life, and I couldn't have asked for better actors. Amy Poehler was great as the lead, and although she wasn't the stand out in this movie, she did a great job. Lewis Black was the best part of this movie, even though you've probably heard that said a million times. With his angry state, he gives the wittiest and most clever lines, and he really made the movie for me. He was the primary reason for my endless laughter in a few scenes, and it's definitely a highlight. I actually really liked Bill Hader as Fear because he also brought a lot of comedy to the movie. As for the other two, there was nothing wrong with them, but they just didn't stick in mind like the other 3 emotions did. Although voice actors always get the praise in animations, you have to give credit to the animators, editors, and writers for this film. This film was beautiful in every way, and the path the director took was great. Everyone can laugh at all the jokes in this movie, but certain jokes are aimed at certain people. Adults and teens can relate to many of the jokes cracked in this movie, and many of them will love it.This movie was made for us to see a great adventure, but in the end, it can really pull on your heart strings. Everything in this movie was there for a purpose, and it was truly worth buying on Blu-Ray.This movie was really made for everyone, and was meant to teach us a lot about our lives. The way our emotions worked as a kid was portrayed perfectly in this movie, and it was exactly how most teens acted. This movie really has an amazing message in the end, and I'm happy that Pixar made such a unique film. In the end, this movie was gorgeous in every way. The voice actors were fantastic, the characters were outstanding, the plot was unique, the adventure was fun, the comedy was gut-busting, the message was heart-warming, and it really gives you a good feeling inside. You can watch this movie whether you're having a good day, or a bad day, and it can make you feel better in the end. I did wish that this movie was a bit longer, because it actually ended around the 1 hour and 28 minute mark, so I was disappointed in that aspect. In all, I give this movie a very strong 4.5/5 stars.

Disney Pixar's "Inside Out" is one movie that will stay in my "cinematic joy" memory bank for a long time. This creative gem focuses on a tween named Riley who moves from Minnesota to San Francisco with her family. Writer-Directors Pete Doctor and Ronnie Del Carmen develop this fascinating film by focusing on the mental emotions inside Riley by developing characters of her emotions; which include Joy, Sadness, Fear, Anger, and Disgust. Not to sound like a Debbie Downer, but my personal cerebral character of the picture was Sadness; actress Phyllis Smith did a stellar vocal performance as Sadness, which ironically brought me much joy in laughter. Anyways, back to the narrative. When things go wrong inside Riley's brain when Joy is jumped out from Riley's memory headquarters, Riley becomes disillusioned about her new life in San Francisco and finds no joy in it. Joy, alongside Sadness, must find their way back to Riley's Cerebral Headquarters before she loses all emotion. Other solid vocal performances came straight outta the mouths of Amy Poehler as Joy, Bill Hader as Fear, and Mindy Kaling as Disgust. "Inside Out" is one smart computer-animated flick you should delve inside to and check out. ***** Excellent

This is the most heartwarming movie I ever seen. After finished watching this, I thought I really want to come back my hometown and meet my family, best friends from high school, and other people who are important to me. Anyway, who didn't watch yet, I will tell you a little summary. First, there was a 11years old girl called Riley. She grew up in Minnesota, and had a good time with her parents, and belonged to ice hokey team. So far, the main point of this movie is five feelings that everybody have in their head. It is Joy, Sadness, Angry, Fear, and Disgusting. These feelings are important to control a humans behavior, like fear helps to avoid dangerous things. Riley was always happy, and a feeling"Joy" was a main part of her head. One day, Riley's father forced to change the place of working, so they were moved together to San Fransisco. At first Riley was excited to start a new life, but in Sun Fransisco, she realized that she doesn't like here. Besides, in first day of school, she cried when she introduce herself. So, other students thought that Riley is a little bit weird. At that time, in her head, something wrong is happen. Sadness sometimes touch the Core memory, which is playing an important role of Riley's life. It means Riley was badly depressed, that even these happy memories changes to sad things. Of course, Riley's parents feels something wrong with their daughter. Mother asks about Riley's school, but Riley said just " It was good, I guess." It was funny when mother sent signal to husband, he was thinking about soccer game, and there were battle in side both heads. It's shows that men and women's are not easily understands each other. Come back to Riley's head, there was another trouble happens. Joy and Sadness were blown away from the head quarters! They tried to go back to head quarters, but realized that it would be takes a long long way. But, Sadness read the all books about head, so she helped Joy as a map. While on the way to head quarters, they found that many island like funny, ice hokey, and friend island was collapsed. Joy was really disappointed. On the other hand, Angry, Disgusting, and Fear doesn't know what to do with Riley, without Joy. One day, when Angry controlled the head quarters, Riley decided to run away from home and go back to Minnesota. She robbed some money from her mothers wallet, and took a bus. Meanwhile, Joy and Sadness met to Binbon, who is the character that Riley create in childhood. Binbon helps them, but he was disappear. Finally, Joy and Sadness could reach to the headquarter, and Joy realized a role of Sadness. Joy passed the control pad to Sadness, and regained Riley's presence of mind. Riley get off the bus, went back to home, and told everything her feelings to parents. This moment, a new core memory was created. It is mix of Joy and Sadness. After this, Riley could get a new friends, and join in the ice hokey team. I really recommend this movie, so you should watch it!

If you've followed my reviews for any length of time, and why the fuck would anyone do that, then you know that, for the most part, I've pretty much been in love with everything Pixar had done up until 2011 when Cars 2 came out. Cars 2 wasn't only awful by Pixar standards, it was awful by anybody's standards. It's not like the first Cars was any great to begin with, but Cars 2 took that very low standard and just went underneath it in every possible way. It was just dreadful. So, ever since then, I've lost a lot of faith in them, this includes the plans to do more sequels to films that don't really need them. Maybe greed finally got to them. Don't get me wrong, Brave and Monster's University were both really good films, even though Monster's University, to me, felt more like a retread as opposed to a step forward, but it's clear that neither of those films were up to Pixar's old standards of excellent in storytelling. The top-notch animation was still there, the storytelling wasn't. So, with Inside Out getting fantastic reviews since its release, I thought that maybe this would've been the resurgence Pixar needed to get back on track and to show others how it's done. Having finally seen the film, however, I'm left with mixed feelings. Do not misunderstand me, this is is an excellent film and one that I would wholeheartedly recommend to people who have grown up with Pixar in their lives, as have I, dating back to actually seeing the original Toy Story in theaters when I was SEVEN years old. I'm 27 years old right now. I vividly still remember going to the theaters to see A Bug's Life, Monster's Inc and The Incredibles. I've also seen Ratatouille, Wall-E, Up and Toy Story 3 in theaters, but those are undeniably closer to who I am now, as a man, than the aforementioned, which were part of my childhood. Inside Out features Pixar at their most inspired in, like, 6 years. It's been SIX fucking years since Pixar actually felt like themselves. And I'm talking about Up here when I refer to them being really inspired. Don't get me wrong, Toy Story 3 is fantastic, and one of Pixar's best (which is funny, because you can say that for, like, 8 of their movies). But that's a sequel and it almost felt like a Disney decision and not Pixar one. I think they, obviously, poured their heart and soul into that film and made it a fantastic film. But I digress, for whatever reason, whether it was Disney or the incredible artists at Pixar suffering through a creative slump, they just haven't felt the same. Like there was that creative spark missing from Cars 2, Brave and Monster's University. Inside Out, however, does give them that spark again, like you can see that this film was a labor of a lot of love from a lot of incredibly talented people. The animation is just absolutely stunningly gorgeous. It's, honestly, some of the best work they've ever done in terms of creating a beautiful and vibrant world. There's, honestly, no competition when it comes to Pixar and the work they do in creating beautiful and detailed worlds. But, and this is just my opinion of course, part of me feels that this what Pixar has in their mind that a Pixar movie should be. Like they're playing with their own rules and what people might expect of them. Honestly, the story, while it does have some beautiful and heartbreaking moments never really clicks for me. At least in terms of everything relating to when Joy and Sadness become separated from the rest of the group (Fear, Anger and Disgust) and Joy's and Sadness' journey, along with Bing Bong (Riley's imaginary friend) back to 'control center', if you will, where all the emotions that Riley ends up feeling are dished out by the appropriate 'worker'. Like, the journey itself, while full of some of the stranger and more surreal images you'll see in any Pixar film, doesn't really click for me. I understand Joy's desperation in getting back to Riley before all the core islands highlighting different aspects of Riley's personality, Happiness Island, Friendship Island, Hockey Island, etc, are wrecked and Joy and Sadness are forgotten forever in an empty pit of other forgotten memories (which ends up leading to one of the film's more heartbreaking moments). I just don't think they did as great a job at making you feel the connection Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear and Disgust end up feeling with Riley. Particularly Joy, who's pretty much obsessed with Riley. After all, all these emotions end up controlling, essentially, Riley's life and how she responds to certain things throughout her life. These...beings, or whatever you wanna call them, are the most essential part of her life and yet, to me, you never really end up feeling that connection. No idea why, it just doesn't click for me. And while Anger, Fear and Disgust are entertaining characters, a lot of their segments at the control center play out exactly the same way, making Riley sadder and sadder. It's necessary in as far as story progression, but it was also a little repetitive. Though I do get its importance in making Riley less and less of the girl her parents knew and how cheerful she could be. With that said, however, I still think the film tackles some pretty hefty themes for what is promoted as a kids' film. Though, honestly, Pixar has always been among the best at bridging the gap. They make things simple enough for kids to enjoy, but mature enough that adults get a lot out of it as well. Though, honestly, this one is probably gonna end up appealing even more to adults than to kids with its themes. Essentially, the film's basic themes are depression and mental health issues. The fact that it's done so in a colorful animated film shouldn't keep anyone with even slight knowledge of how the human mind works to know that this is a film about depression and mental health issues. I think this subtler, more understated story is the best part of the film, to be honest. It plays with that concept in an intelligent fashion that highlights a spotlight that is very rarely spoken about in films like this. I'm not saying that these elements should've been more prominently featured, I prefer that it's more subtle, but I just wish that the journey of Joy, Sadness and Bing Bong would've been as satisfying as the thoughts the film puts in your head with its approach to depression. Hopefully it opens up discussion these issues and how it's important to address them. The film also, rightfully, tackles about how sadness is just as essential a part of who we are as people as happiness is. Joy wants Riley to always be happy, similar to every human being on earth, but the fact of the matter is that this is not achievable in a realistic manner. There are days where you're gonna be sad, mad, lethargic, afraid and that's all fine. It's part of what makes us who we are as human beings and I think that they were smart to tackle such a hefty subject matter in such a mature and intelligent fashion. The film is certainly funny and entertaining enough, it's supremely well-written, despite some hiccups, and the voice acting is, as is typical, outstanding. Amy Poehler, Phyllis Smith and Richard Kind are all pretty incredible in their roles and they bring a lot of life and energy to the film with their performances. Part of me wants to give this film 4.5 stars, but there's also the aspects of the film that I didn't like that clearly keep it from reaching that point. Though, intellectually speaking, this film is at a level above anything Pixar has ever done, to the point that a lot of your kids simply won't understand a lot of the film and why it was doing certain things. Its exploration of the brain and how it affects your personality is really intriguing though and I'd, just for that, recommend the movie. But I think the movie definitely has a lot more to offer than that. It's entertaining, beautiful and heartbreaking in equal measure. So, yes, Pixar has made the comeback. Maybe not the comeback of the year, because this is still just a notch below their truly elite offerings, but I'd still call this an excellent movie and one that I enthusiastically recommend. Bring on Pixar's next film The Good Dinosaur, which comes out in 3 weeks. Gonna be an interesting test to see if their quality can hold up with two releases coming out within 5 months of each other. Here's to hoping that it's another excellent offering from Pixar.

As Toy Story will forever make us wonder what exactly goes on when we close a door, Inside out will forever change the way we think about the inner workings of our own minds. Delightfully innovative and upbeat, Inside Out is a wonderfully expressed journey of conviction, taking viewers on the rollercoaster of life's ups and downs in a thrilling, humorous and heart-felt adventure.Growing up isn't always easy as 11 year old Riley finds out when she is uprooted from her ice-hockey loving life in Minnesota for the broccoli pizza eating city of San Francisco. Guided through the turmoil by her emotions - Joy (Amy Poehler), Fear (Bill Hader), Anger (Lewis Black), Disgust (Mindy Kaling) and Sadness (Phyllis Smith), Riley remains positive about her new home, school and making friends. But when things in emotional headquarters start to go array, usual leader Joy might not always remain in control and new balance will need to be struck. The Verdict: Colourful, exhilarating and fresh, this is Pixar at its very best. Published : Canberra Weekly MagazineDate of Publication : 02/07/2015

When discussing the merit of Inside Out, it's easy to bypass the whole cutesy children's movie angle for what it really is-an innovative, thrilling, psychological lesson we can all learn from. The characters, namely Bing Bong and Joy, are complex yet easy to like. It's another smash hit in the storied history of Pixar.

Riley, a normal schoolgirl, she has five feelings and emotions. They are called joy, anger, fear, sadness, and disgust. These feelings control and inspire her everyday movements, decisions, and her memory.Riley was born in Minnesota, within her mind, 5 emotions came to life. They live in the headquarters of Riley's emotional brain, the conscious mind, where all five of them control Riley's actions, emotions, and memories using a control console. The memories are stored in a ball shaped thing, which are sent into the storage.One day, Riley's father moves to San Francisco. Joy becomes concerned that sadness keeps touching happy memories, so she tries to keep her isolated from the group. Sadness, though, accidentally caused Riley to cry in front of the class, Creating a new sad core memory, which is the most important memories. Joy tries to take the memory out before it reaches the core hub, but she accidentally knocks out some of the other core memories, causing the island controlled by the memories to shut down. Before Joy can put those memories back in place, they are sucked up in the memory tube and in the labyrinth of the brain, where long-term memories are stored and kept. Anger, Fear, and Disgust attempt to make Riley happy and control the console despite Joy's absence. Anger believes that Riley needs to go back to Minnesota to create more happy memories. As a result, Anger plugs in an idea into the console.Meanwhile, in the storage of Riley's long-term memories, Joy and Sadness finds Riley's imaginary friend, Bing-Bong. They asked Bing-Bong how to get back to the headquarters. Bing-Bong tells them they can ride the train of thought. Sadly, before they arrived, Riley slept and the train shut down. Joy and Sadness tried to wake Riley up, and it succeeded accidentally when she had a bad dream. Joy and the others took the train again, but it broke down when another island fell to the memory dump, where forgotten stuff are kept. Joy tries to get back to the console using a recall tube, but it broke, sending Joy and Bing-Bong into the dump. Joy saw a small wagon. Joy and Bing-Bong rode the wagon, trying to get out of the dump. After several failed attempts, Bing-Bong realizes that the combined weight is too heavy. As a result, he jumps of the wagon, allowing joy to reach the islands. Joy uses various tools, including imaginary boyfriends from imagination island and got back to headquarters successfully with sadness.When Joy and Sadness got back to the Headquarters, Joy encourages sadness to pull out the idea, and Sadness successfully pulled it out, reactivating the console and making Riley return home.Once Riley returned home, she broke down in tears and confessed she missed her own life. Her parents comforted her, and after that, together, Joy and Sadness together made a mixed feeling core memory, which naturally created a new island, a year later, Riley slowly adapts to her new life, turning her into a more emotionally complex girl, with more islands and core memories .

Inside Out is easily the riskiest movie Disney Pixar has ever produced and also the most challenging one yet. It tells the story of young Riley who is forced to move to San Francisco and how her emotions, which are joy, sadness, disgust, anger and fear navigates her through this extremely emotional point in her life. It is a genuine and heart-felt story filled with emotionally relatable characters. One of my favorite movies of the year, Inside Out sets out to do what it aims. It makes you fall in love with all the fantastically animated emotions, it makes you cry as it reminds you certain things that you have experienced in your life, it makes you fell okay about crying and most of all, it makes you love your family and friends even though the times are tough. I cannot point out any negatives about this movie since it was an thoroughly emotional experience for me and very rarely does a movie makes me feel this way.It is a triumph of animation and story-telling through well directed characters and dialogues. The actors who lent their voice to the characters did a fantastic job especially Amy Poehler as joy, Phyllis Smith as sadness and Richard Kind as Bing Bong. Inside Out is a genius and rare convergence of humor and emotions. This is a movie so spectacular, one can never forget.

When Inside Out released in June, it had been two years since Disney Pixar released Monsters University in 2013. With the Summer 2014 The Good Dinosaur being postponed (now coming out November 2015), Pixar animation had to once again prove itself. After its conception in the 90's, Pixar rattled off blockbuster after blockbuster with each of their movies receiving 90+% on Rotten Tomatoes (Cars being the exception). Yet, with Cars 2 (39%), Brave (78%) and Monsters University (78%) many questioned where Pixar was heading... Until now. Inside Out, is a story about a happy go-lucky hockey loving 11 year-old whose world is turned upside down when her parents move her to San Francisco. She is run by the emotions in her head, Joy, Sadness, Disgust, Fear and Anger. The movie is incredibly hilarious as times, and downright sad in others, but it is the realness of the story that hits home for its viewers. Few animated movies have the courage to make a movie where a character is truly sad, nearing depression about her current situation. Inside Out moves past its string of sequels and we've seen this before movies to bring us the type of original idea that made us love Pixar in the first place. With just over two months until the release of The Good Dinosaur, which was postponed 18 months because it wasn't ready, we can't wait to see Pixars' next original title, because for the first time in a long time, they are trending in the right direction.

Pixar has always made films that are tailored to audiences young and old, yet "Inside Out" is made in a way that appeals to an even larger audience than that.Pixar films are typically for younger audiences, yet to help keep adults and parents interested they include witty dialogue and parts that only adults can understand. That's not to say that "Inside Out" does not do this as well. It does, yet again it does even more.There are films where you can just sit back and enjoy the show and not have to think about anything. An example being classic Hollymood Musicals like, "Singin' In The Rain". But there are also films where you have to stay attentive throughout the entire thing or else you will be completely lost. Such are movies like, "Inception"."Inside Out", however, is a combination of both these styles of film. You can watch the film mindlessly or contemplate everything that's going on in a current scene, but it will still be enjoyable either way. For this reason, the movie can be watched repetitively because its different depending on how you watch it.And unlike other Pixar films which narrate the fictional adventures of toys, bugs, fish or even rats in Paris! "Inside Out" is a fictional twist on a non-fiction subject; human emotions. Its a movie about all of us.The movie explores human psychology and the importance and science of our emotions and personality, all the while sticking to the Pixar formula we all know and love! There's something for everyone; loveable characters, adventure, comedy, suspense, wit, surprise, horror, and moments which make us cry our eyes out! "Inside Out" not only sets the bar for other animation companies, it also "one-ups" its predecessing movies, further increasing the quality we will now expect from future Pixar films.In conclusion, "Inside Out" is in my opinion the best Pixar film ever made! It is what you would expect from a Pixar film, yet its surprisingly far more than that.

With the recent Pixar movies, it seems to me that they are putting more effort on trying to intrigue all ages not just only children anymore. This movie is about a young girl moving into a new city as her emotions navigate her decisions. One emotion which is Joy get into a conflict and is in search of a solution but while she is on this journey she learns a lot about Sadness and her part in the young girl life. As she evolves on this journey, as do the other emotions and the young girl. First off, the images and sound play a huge part in this movie as it adds all the emotions needed in the pictures. It gives us a different perspective in how our emotions bleed out to others and how creative we forget we can be. The director does well in this part as he gives different scenes that are out of this world mostly on Joy journey as you would not expect most of the stuff happening seeing greed, selfishness, and others which you wouldn't presume to happen in a "young movie." He gives you a different picture on life and how generally our society forgets how we could view it from all different sides. The director also actively engages the audience as Joy goes on a journey to rescue the girls Morals or Personality that she obtain throughout her life. Certainly A movie that made me tear up is a first as it is hard for a guy to cry sometimes. What could have been worked on is the music as it should really amplify more of the scene rather than a little aggression. Some felt like it was lackluster as it was a powerful scene. As for the voices of each character, I believe it was splendid as Angry had the right tone of voice and sarcasm. Disgust had this almost blonde personality but what really gave in was Bing Bong played by Richard King, he put so much emotion and thought in his voice that it felt so real in the movies. The usage of colors allows more eye candy in the different section of the movies that appealed to the audience giving them not a monotone view but at time vibrant for happy feeling and same suit color for sadness. Overall this movie 9/10 as there is some part that are a little off but the plot, character, and voices were on point. Other than that the movie is about 1 hour and 30mins giving it a perfect time for the plot to end, nothing I felt was rushed as everything flowed nicely. This movie oddly relates a lot to our daily lives as our emotions get in a way with a lot of our decision-making comprising some paths that we choose but also how we deal with other people in our daily lives. Our choices and voice make big decision in other views as working with others to make a better place.

Little kids will enjoy the adventure, the gags and the characters, adults will enjoy the symbolic level of the movie, if they pay attention to details and accept to play with the metaphor behind the movie : from color choice to little details of scenes, nothing is there without a meaning, in a Pixar movie.

Growing up can be a bumpy road, and it's no exception for Riley, who is uprooted from her Midwest life when her father starts a new job in San Francisco. Like all of us, Riley is guided by her emotions - Joy, Fear, Anger, Disgust and Sadness. The emotions live in Headquarters, the control center inside Riley's mind, where they help advise her through everyday life. As Riley and her emotions struggle to adjust to a new life in San Francisco, turmoil ensues in Headquarters. Although Joy, Riley's main and most important emotion, tries to keep things positive, the emotions conflict on how best to navigate a new city, house and school. Written by Pixar.

Disney continues to impress with this clever and creative creation. An ambitious animation that truly could have gone disastrous, but ended as a critical and box-office masterpiece. 'Inside Out' might at first glance look like a childish 1.5 hour-'Minions-sequel'. But that's just what the kids will see, meanwhile we older individuals will embrace this amazingly visualized plot where emotions and everyday problems are experienced. Everything from within is seen from a new perspective, and it truly is a ride of joy, emotions and surprisingly much action-sequences. The concept works for everyone; both the humor, the relatable and enduring aspects. The characters are just as relatable, there's much development to them too and they are so well envisioned in a such beautiful-animated way. It's like magic. To take our ordinary life and put it out in different characters with specific emotions; that's an ambitious idea, even for Disney! But they managed to come up with this extraordinary world that works so well, and that totally makes one crave for more popcorn! It might be one of the most flawless movies of 2015, with its stunning focus on imaginative and deep characters. The first 15 minutes of the opening shots might be a bit too fast and it could have been a bit less rushed - if you look at such small critical details. It also got some very minor fact-based reaction-dialogs. But the rushed opening later on did slow down considerably, and truly managed to grasp the depth of the characters and the clever plot that never stopped being inventive! So to keep it short; 'Inside Out' is without any doubt another great animation by the Disney-Pixar corporation, and that got a lot to tell about family, emotions, everyday life and every individual's own mind. Go watch it.Personal rating: 8.5/10 Critical rating: 9.5/10

A brilliant idea that shines for the first few minutes and gradually dies out for the rest of the film due to the lack of animation creativity and deep script, hmmm, this sounds familiar to me. Ah yes, "Up" - a profoundly creative and emotional ... short film of first-ten-minutes coupled with an utterly boring full length animation that follows. They might share the same director, right? Bingo! Indeed "Inside Out" has a very good premise - the simplification of human's feelings and thinkings into some distinctive factors, but its execution is somehow boring, full of clich�s, repetitive scripts, few emotional moments that were dwarfed by the same monotonous set-pieces like "Monsters, Inc." (which was directed by, obviously, the same director). A human mind is always something fascinating, but its depiction here in "Inside Out" is disappointing with not much creativity put into its vast boring emptiness of a landscape. Basically the film has no "villain", but the poorly-developed characters themselves are already villains to the audience - why does Joy (should have been "Optimism") always lead instead of Sadness (should have been "Pessimism"), given the psychological fact that sadness is, in most case, the most memorable feelings in our memory? Why does Disgust need to be here, given another psychological fact that it is way less important in our mind than, let's say, imagination, creativity, or especially desire? And why in the world do emotions prevail reasons in controlling our everyday life? The simplification of the mind is acceptable if it brings out a clear, coherent, and fascinating "inside out" portrait of our mind, our emotions. But if such simplification only induces misunderstanding and incoherence, than it is simply a failed effort. I understand that the journey of Joy, Sadness et al. is only an euphemistic depiction of the changes in the mind of a coming-of-age girl in new situation, but her emotional journey is disappointingly uneventful and thus could not bring any weight to her "inside journey". Still, the film is very OK as an entertaining piece, but its lack of creativity and caring execution is unforgivable. It will be very sad if this film wins another Oscar for Peter Docter, such winning only gives way for more unimaginative animations and a poorer taste by the audience.

You don't need me to tell you that "Inside Out" is one of the best films of the year because every other review is telling you the exact same thing. At the time of this writing, there are only five negative reviews out of nearly two hundred and seventy- that, in a nutshell, shows how impressive this Disney-Pixar outing is. Starring the five core emotions that run a little girl's brian, "Inside Out" shows how everyone has to deal with the tough emotions of going through change. In the course of the film, the home to the emotions, Riley, is forced to give up her friends, her school, and her home to move thousands of miles away. Then, when Joy (Amy Poehler) and Sadness (Phyllis Smith) are lost in the depth's of Riley's mind, everything falls apart. By the end, Joy, who had been dominating Riley's emotions, realizes that everyone needs a little sadness, a little disgust, a little fear, and even a little anger to get through growing up. Lewis Black shines as Anger; every line he yelled was pure gold. And the secret weapon, Richard Kind as Riley's old imaginary friend Bing Bong, was beautifully used to bring the realism of growing up to the big screen. In short, "Inside Out" might just prove to be one of the best films of the year.

It is such a joy to report that Pixar is back in form. After a few years of weak soup, it's so nice to see them back on the track that made us fall in love with their confections in the first place. In the animation game, Pixar was always been the better factory, churning out creative projects that were destined to last for generations while their rivals simply spat out quickly made product mounted solely on what was popular at the moment. But after Up six years ago, the studio seemed to have lost its way and they haven't produced greatness since. At least, until now.Inside Out is a grand and bold work of imagination and creativity, made by people who are not content to give the audience the bargain basement, but to offer something that is going to last. Thematically, it resembles Toy Story 2 in that it is also about the pangs and stresses of growing up and losing the most valued trappings of childhood as adolescence washes ashore.The movie, for the most part, takes place inside the head of Reilly Anderson, an 11 year-old girl from a nice family who is suffering the slings and arrows of approaching adolescence. Inside her brain is the complex that make up the core of her being, driven by the aforementioned Joy (voiced by Amy Poehler); Sadness (voiced by Phyllis Smith from "The Office"), Fear (voiced by Bill Hader) who looks like a question mark; Anger (Lewis Black) who dresses like middle-management; And Disgust (voiced by Mindy Kailing), a green shimmering ball of teenage dismissiveness.Of course, this is not the most original plot in the world. I think immediately of the early 90s sitcom "Herman's Head" which had the same plot only the protagonist was a grown man. There was the Eddie Murphy comedy Meet Dave, and horror adventures like The Cell and Identity. I can also think of a bit once written by Woody Allen that takes place inside the body of a man during his mating ritual.The movie is original in it's approach. It begins on the day Reilly is born as the palette of her inner being begins to form. First a ball of light, then a pixie figure called Joy. Little Reilly's mind is a blank slate that very quickly forms the emotional core of her being. Along with Joy come Sadness, Fear, Anger and Disgust. What her mind eventually evolves into is a complex of emotions, feelings, trains of thought, ideas, images, moods and memories. What she carries with her, what she keeps, and what she dismisses are at the core of this very impressive visual textbook, one that not only forms into a visual masterwork, but also one of the most creative and ambitious animated features in many years. This is what animated movies are all about.The quintet at the controls all form the core of Reilly's current mood. Joy seems to have the lead most of the time, but there's never a sense that anyone is elbowing anyone out of the way. Everyone has their turn at the console of Reilly's current emotional state. The key battle comes between Joy and Sadness. Joy sees Sadness as an unnecessary element to Reilly's state of harmony, but Sadness knows that in order to achieve harmony one must experience sadness to get to joy.Every minute of every day, Reilly's brain produces a memory that is represented as a tiny marble colored by whatever emotional state the memory comes from. Those memories are either stored in Long Term; stored in a special place for Core Memories; or are disposed of all together. What comes of Reilly's current experience is juxtaposed by what has happened before. New things come in and old things go out - some are stored in her long term memory, some are buried in her subconscious, and old, forgotten memories are deposited into a dark chasm where they eventually evaporate from existence much like a deleted file on a computer. Her current emotional state is also represented by various theme parks that begin operating based on her current state of mind representing Family, Honesty, Hockey (her favorite past time) and her moments of Goofball playfulness.The drama begins with a change in Reilly's life. Her parents are uprooting from Minnesota to San Francisco, meaning that Reilly has to leave behind friends, and the best memories of her childhood. Her churning emotional states breed confusion, and anger, and resentment forcing a battle between Joy and Sadness mostly due to Joy's concern that Sadness will infect core memories (when she touches them they turn blue). The two end up outside the command center with no way to get back, leaving Reilly's supplementary emotions, Fear, Anger and Disgust at the controls. What lies on the other side is the strangest journey since Alice fell down the rabbit hole. Joy and Sadness take a strange journey through the recesses of Reilly's ever-changing brain, particularly the Long Term memory library that is often cleared out when Reilly no longer needs them.The script draws a very clean line between what is happening to Reilly in the world and the universe inside her head. Things are changing, evolving, breaking down, rebuilding - in other words, she's growing up. And just as Reilly doesn't understand these changes, neither do the representations in her brain. The tragedy of what happens to the trappings of childhood once Reilly has moved past them is a key theme here, expressed most achingly in the form of a circus elephant named Bing-Bong (beautifully voiced by Richard Kind), who once served as Reilly's imaginary friend, but now lingers in the forgotten realms of her brain, always aware that he is many years late for the memory dump. Bing-Bong is a tragic figure who, much like Jessie the Cowgirl in Toy Story 2, is a figure whose purpose dried up long ago. He serves as a guide to get Joy and Sadness on board Reilly's train of thought and back to the control center even though everyone knows his eventual fate.The journey getting back to the control center is a trip through a virtual psychology textbook including a a trip through the memory dump where all of her useless memories are dried up and forgotten. Then a creepy journey into Reilly's subconscious, where Joy and Sadness come across an oversized clown who isn't evil, but is terrifying in the way that a small child might see it. He's a giant, but only because that's how Reilly saw him in real life.But the most bizarre sequence comes when the trio takes a shortcut through a forbidden realm called Abstract Thought where the three figures find themselves misshapen into a cubist state then into a flattened out form representative of early European animation. It's a fun sequence - a head scratcher - but a fun sequence none-the-less.Much more of the plot, I cannot discuss. What has been described here only scratches the surface. Let me just say that as with last year's The LEGO Movie, this is an animated feature made with loving care, a story told by writers and animators that aren't satisfied to nail down their story to a pat formula or to whatever colorful bupkis they can sell at McDonald's. The people behind Inside Out - that being screenwriters Meg LeFauve, Josh Cooley, and Peter Docter writing from a story by Reynoldo del Carmen - want to make something special, something that will linger in your mind. They've taken the animated genre and they've stretched it to the limit in an effort to create something special. They've created a great journey, an emotional journey. One that will last for generations to come.

Beyond all doubt, Inside Out is - as I write this - the best film I've seen all year. No, this isn't hyperbole talking. It's THAT good. The movie manages to make you feel a colourful spectrum of "human emotion" whilst never feeling manipulative or melodramatic. I've seen a lot of tear-jerkers in my lifetime, but never has one been this bittersweet - pushing you to the brink of tears multiple times while somehow still leaving a big old smile on your face as you exit the cinema. Unsurprisingly though, audience members at each of the THREE screenings I attended were mostly adults. Whilst other studios insist on making adult-friendly movies for kids, Pixar continues to make kid-friendly movies for adults, which has been a big factor in their films transcending age for almost 20 years now since the first Toy Story. Final thought: There's a beautiful and encouraging message here on why sometimes in life it's important to feel certain emotions, and that it's OK when you do.
