"Pixar has done it again", those words have been slowly diminishing from Pixar's dictionary throughout the years. With above average outings and sequels to established franchises, there were doubts and chatters among audience, "maybe Pixar's lost their magic", "Creativity is down the drain with Pixar" and whatnot. Inside Out is here to prove the naysayers wrong and completely refill the wavering magic gauge, maximum to the very brim. Before we begin exploring Inside Out, as with Pixar's trend, the movie is soft-booted with a short movie titled "Lava", a tale of a dormant and not-so-dormant volcano falling/finding for love, all this is depicted via singing and beautifully crafted images that oozes with color and life. As short movies come and go, I was touched by its tale but at the very core it was pretty simple and flat for Pixar's standard and this doesn't indicate that it was bland, the message was very clear but it just lacks that extra level of creativity that's very well honed by Pixar. Getting to the bone of the topic, Inside Out is a story that asks the viewer a question, what if, just what if our feelings/emotions had characters and what if in a secret compartment in our head, each of these feelings ranging from, fear, happiness, sadness, disgust and anger controlled our reactions towards situation that arise in our daily life. For each and every human being the main emotion in control differs, some people are extremely joyous and for them "joy" will be the central figure, while others are very short tempered and for those you have "anger" being the boss. This is the fundamental concept behind Inside Out, we live through the life of Riley from a first person and third person point of view, gaining deep inside on how each and every actions of hers is managed and well-maintained for her betterment and how these emotions despite having definite characteristics all root for Riley's overall happiness. Inside Out is a pretty complicated movie that explains how the feelings function through well-explained exposition that ensures it's best to not feel too preachy but you do feel there's tons of topic to go through in order to fully enjoy the meal that is Inside Out. From, how do short term memory, long term memory, memory dumps, central core memories, imagination land to abstract thinking, *phew* the list goes on and on. I did wonder at one point how would a child crunch on all these information loaded to them, would they fully understand it or at the least get a rough idea enough to enjoy the hijinks of the emotions. Inside Out does all it can to keep it kid-friendly with comical explanation, bizarre situations that span out in each area to further tackle the different worlds within the brain all packed full with comedy, slapstick and whatnot. Though I sincerely believe, Inside Out is an animation disguised as a kid's film meant for adults who still have a little kid in them. It doesn't go absolutely Nolan on us, but just enough to keep us wondering and hoping for much more, if only school taught us science like this, if only. The plot starts out with decent pacing to flesh out the characters both in the head and those in the flesh of the character and give us a rather welcoming feel to this new Pixar world. The very crux of the movie lies when Happy and Sadness go on journey in the brain when a technical accident occurs in the central core, leaving fellow emotions lost in a maze of creativity trying the best to get back to the central core because even you could imagine how one's life would be without happiness and sadness and there's where the plot's true moral of the story comes in, the punchline. I did not see it coming and I bet it will keep you guessing what's coming next and hit you in the face like a sucker punch of packaged emotions. A very good lesson to learn in life in fact, something very relatable and agreeable. There is no such thing as completely one emotion to live your life through and the sooner you accept it, the happier you will embrace your life, this is well the vague spoiler-free version, but you'll get the gist of it. The characters aren't one dimensional, one trick-ponies, no sir. Even though, they are an embodiment of one emotion, say "Happiness" one could argue, how could there be character development if the very existence of said character is to be happy. Well, Pixar is prepared to prove you wrong together with the jolly Amy Poehler voicing "Joy" the protagonist, or to be more precise the true protagonist behind the scene of Riley's mind, on a personal level, knowing that Park and Rec fame Amy Poehler giving life to this character only felt natural and in fact an extension of her character from the television show, an extended acting if you will. The characters evolve and you as a viewer would love one character one point and switch to disliking it midway and at the very end(hopefully) accepting both of them for what they are, as how the character accept the reality of the situation. The emotions aren't the only ammo in this shell-case, there's a wide variety of side-characters and namely one unforgettable hero, Bing Bong, a truly misunderstood character with a very tragic life. Even if Riley forgot Bing Bong, I promise I won't. This is where Pixar shines, even if Bing Bong is a side-character, a plot device to attune Joy and Sadness towards their right path, he still shines wonderfully with heart. As Joy and Sadness, learn about each other through their travels we too as viewers engage in that well-crafted relationship that starts rather straight out obvious and absolutely taking a 360 degrees turn into unknown territory, a volatile yet satisfying relationship. We connect with the characters on an emotional level and manly tears were shed upon multiple occasions where you could feel the grit and passion of these characters through hardship and sacrifice, a bond like no other. Comedy is top notch, there is the usual slapstick comedy meant for kids, the adults would just pass a smile and there is the universal bone-tickler that sees no age or maturity. A lot of clever jokes too and some even touching DreamWorks crude adult humor, all-in-all, comedy for the whole family, Pixar never goes wrong here. Usually I'd discuss in length on how well the CG is executed with the expected usage of the word "eye-candy" but through my experience I was so lost in the largely built worlds within the brain that I did not actively start picking up on creative technical cues. At the same time the CG isn't truly groundbreaking but lives to meet the expectation that we expect from a Pixar outing. Inside Out is Pixar's game on face, I can't wait to experience "The Good Dinosaur" which hits cinema near the end of this year. With an extraordinary story infused with loveable characters and jolly good comedy, Inside Out is a masterpiece to stay in our minds and hearts like its predecessors, ever memorable. I would really love to visit the world of Inside Out again, there is so much more to be explored in the brain, character dynamics and emotions to be discovered even, who knows, maybe one fine day. On the downside, there are some plot holes that occur directly close to the epic finale, whether the director noticed it through the chaotic sequence or not would be a good debate but it does make one wonder whether this method of reaching the central core could have been achieved much earlier instead of having an insane number of Uncharted/Tomb Raider bad luck moments with crumbling skyscrapers to so-close-but-not-that-close moments but luckily it doesn't deter the experience as a whole, noticeable but forgivable. PS: The end credits is a jolly good one, we enter the minds of various people that the character Riley meets throughout her life including dogs and cats. A fun take-out, clearly to put a smile on your face after that emotional ending.

The concept of Inside Out is one which you could expand at least into twenty films. Focusing on the five different emotions (joy, sadness, fear, anger, disgust) inside the head of its main character, the 11-year old Riley, the film inevitably makes you think what would all this look like from the perspective of a teenager, a senior, or your own. But regardless, this is a film in which everyone can find something to relate to. Inside Out is every bit as heartfelt, funny and instructive as you'd expect from Pixar, but it's also surprisingly thoughtful and multi-layered. The surrealistic adventures of the different emotions (displayed as brilliantly comic caricatures) inside Riley's head are not just ludicrous madness, but a constant reflection of what's happening in reality and what Riley is going through. Unpicking all the clever metaphors and parallels that writer-director Peter Docter and his writing team have injected into the film is what makes it a masterwork worthy of repeated viewings. But above all, Inside Out touches your heart with its beautifully human central message: emotions, even difficult ones, are something that everyone just have to learn to accept, and sadness is just as inevitable and necessary as joy. To say that a film makes you feel better about yourself and makes you want to be more open when it comes to emotional difficulties is a praise that few films deserve these days.

Inside Out is one of the most amazing films I've ever seen. I'm writing this on my phone right now, just right after walking out of the cinemas. Animation is only for children? Puh-lease. Inside Out proves otherwise.I honestly feel like Inside Out wasn't made for tweeny boopers; it was made for it's older audience, the audience that grasps its message fully and tuck it into their long term memory. I feel more moved than it than ever. It's hard to write a review without spoiling anything, so I'll just say this: Inside Out will remind you of your childhood. It will remind you of growing up, and everything that goes along with it. And most importantly, it will remind you how to feel.But the best part of Inside Out is that is says this: it's okay to feel sad. It's okay to feel lonely. It's okay to feel hurt, and angry, and scared, and disgusted. All these emotions are natural and needed and they work together. I'm so glad this movie was made; it's so timely and wonderful. It's the movie we never knew we needed.This may not prove a point because I cry in movies a lot (I cry way too easily. Guess sadness is in charge during movie marathons.) but I'll say it anyway - Inside Out broke my heart and made me cry more times than any movie has ever had. There were so many emotional moments and never once did they feel forced or manipulating - they felt so raw and genuine, making touching its audience feel effortless.This movie is not one to be missed. It's well worth the admission price. And I'll be rooting for it for all of the awards shows next year...but wait....The Little Prince...Congratulations, Pixar. You did it again.

This is such a smart and clever animated movie about our feelings, personalities, and how we change. I'm sure some of the concepts and messages built into the film may be lost on the younger set, but the complexity of what is presented is surprisingly digestible due to the imaginative yet enlightening internal world of the mind created in the film.The movie certainly has its humorous parts, but there definitely were some pretty poignant moments as well. I really appreciated how the movie stayed true to itself by letting us feel all the emotions... joy, fear, anger, disgust, and fear. It could have let us coast on the positivity of joy, but beyond the creative animation this movie demonstrated real emotional depth. It eloquently illustrates the fact we are humans that feel a range of emotions, and it can in fact be harmful if we don't allow ourselves to feel them. This is a great films for kids and adults alike. Kids learn important lessons about expressing their feelings and how they can overcome challenges. And for adults, the movie creatively reveals all that can go on inside of us and others; and that with that understanding we are reminded to let ourselves and others feel what we need to feel. We gain insight that denying our emotions may stifle our personal growth and connection with others.

It's not perfect, but it's exactly what you'd want from a Pixar film: heartfelt, funny and at times almost cathartic. It's simple in message but that message is a fundamentally necessary one; opening up a dialogue about feelings and emotions is something our society needs, perhaps now more than ever, and I'm so glad we have a film like this for young children and adults alike to enjoy, discuss and possibly (definitely) cry over. Conceptually, it's intriguing and highly original, and while it may get convoluted at times, by the end its message is plain for all to see. If it's a choice between this and the Minions, see this one.

Taking moviegoers in and out and shaking all about a young girl to her emotional core, Pixar's awe-strikingly creative latest charts among the studio's best and ballsiest. Talk about cerebral. Of course, Pixar always appeals to gray matter as much as the funny bone, but this psychological amusement park ride takes it to a whole other level. You know how people knock small jobs with the dismissive expression 'It isn't brain surgery'? Well, Inside Out kind of IS brain surgery. It's no small job to literally characterize emotions and show how they have to work together to form a well-balanced person. But this inventive family flick accomplishes this and elicits a great deal of true emotion from the audience as well. The sputtering breakdown Cars 2 notwithstanding, Pixar vows to never release a feature until it's as good a film as the animation house is capable of creating. Inside Out proves no exception to this rule, succeeding on most every level. Informative without being too brainy and funny without being too pedestrian, the film nonetheless represents a huge gamble for Pixar. Perhaps, the film's only brain freeze proves to be the fact that, despite the winning characters, it goes above the head of the younger set. The Junior Freud explanations will confuse anybody under 6, but the writers nonetheless do an expert job of breaking down a rational animal into a team sport. In this G-rated animated flick, a young girl's emotions get plunged into chaos as they compete for control of her mind after she leaves her friends and moves to a new home across the country. It takes one of their most expert craftsmen and biggest risk-takers, to mold and shape this high-concept cartoon into a highly entertaining biology lesson. Pete Docter (Up) deserves much credit for thinking outside of the box by going inside the head. Thankfully, in Joy, Anger, Disgust, Fear and Sadness, he gives us amazing characters with - ironically - a good amount of emotional depth. A pitch-perfect voice cast including Amy Poehler, Lewis Black, Mindy Kaling, Bill Hader and Phyllis Smith, however, colors in these colorful characters all the more.Bottom line: Emotional Rescue

Inside Out is a funny, heartwarming, and deep journey into the human mind. Pixar has a filmography that's hard to match, and things will remain that way if they keep putting out films of this caliber. As per usual the story is well crafted, and inventive, but the most impressive thing is the use of humor to help the moments of true drama. By that I mean the film has a relatable humor, that anybody can laugh at and have a good time with, so when the film decides to get serious it hits the audience even deeper. This something Pixar's always been good at, but this movie has some of the most touching moments since Up. On top of the brilliant use of humor, the visuals are stunning, the voice acting is perfect, and the characters are surprisingly well crafted. In the end Inside Out is one of Pixar's best films in the last 5 years, and is worth seeing on the big screen.

- Inside OutBranded as the first original Pixar movie since Brave (which was barely an "original" film), Inside Out is exactly what anyone would expect to see in a "good" Pixar Movie: masterfully written, grand in ambition, effortlessly joyful and undeniably moving.With the "what-if" idea that is usually present in classic Pixar films, Pete Docter decides to focus on one single coming-of-age girl, in what is actually a coming of age film, disguised as an animated film. The film started out with Riley opening her eyes for the first time. Appeared in her mind was Joy, as she provides voice-over of her first few seconds with Riley. Then came Sadness, who Joy fears the most. After that, the headquarters got bigger with Fear, Disgust and Anger, each with their own responsibility and task to keep Riley, well, Riley. Each of their actions creates memories, with some memories turning into "Core Memories", which form Riley's personality, and in Riley's head, islands. After 11 years of being in charge of Riley's mind, Joy still can't figure out Sadness' duties and responsibilities. One day, Riley's family moved to San Francisco, which caused chaos in Headquarters. Joy tried to keep Riley on a happy mood, but on the first day of school, Sadness accidentally affected a Core Memory with sadness, and as Joy tries to keep everything in place, Joy was sucked into the Memory Tube, as well as Sadness, as they are dumped down to Long-Term Memories. Upon trying to find a way out, Sadness and Joy stumbled across Riley's former imaginary friend, Bing Bong. Bing Bong agreed to help Sadness and Joy back to The Headquarters, but only if Joy agrees to remind Riley of Bing Bong again. Back at Headquarters, Fear, Anger and Disgust struggled to keep Riley the same person, but was unable to and as a result, spiraled Riley's life out of control, as she sassed her parents and ditched her friends. Anger then came up with an "Idea", which was shown as a lightbulb in the film, for Riley to run away from home. Joy, Sadness and Bing Bong must get back to Headquarters on time in order to bring Riley back to her life.Pixar was in a crisis phase before they had Inside Out, with their qualities dwindling because of their lack of original ideas and over reliance on unfavorable sequels (looking at you Cars 2) after it's collaboration with Walt Disney Pictures With Inside Out, Pixar brought back one of it's core players, Pete Docter (the man behind Monster Inc., Up) and boy, was it a masterstroke. Described by many as Docter's passion project, Docter took full advantage of his creative freedom with the film to craft an imaginary land inside a little girl's head, which was visually stunning and colorfully broad. The script itself is going down in history as one of the few original ideas left in Hollywood that manages to connect with a wide variety of audience: everyone has been through rough patches, whether it is moving houses, socially crippled or puberty, basically, but the script masterfully, and deliberately, hid it behind all the inventiveness and originality of the film. The layers of the story perfectly align with the film's hidden tone (a girl who is having difficulties with growing up decides to run away from home), powered with delightfully-written dialogue and emotional segments, especially the deeply written third act of the movie, which was one of the most memorable sequence of the decade, that ended with most of the audience reaching for the tissues (if they had prepared one)It was aided by colorful characters, which were memorable in their own rights: the optimistic Joy, the moody Sadness and the imaginative imaginary friend Bing Bong (we all had one, you know, the one who cries candies, is an animal-fantasy creature hybrid and had a rocking spaceship) to name a few. The character development doesn't take a huge role in the film, but as the film progresses, we can see how the characters have grown out of their original ideas, with Joy being more down-to-earth and calm, Sadness being happier (which wasn't supposed to happen, but since this is an animated movie, even a flying house is considered normal) and Riley being more mature. All of the film's more subtle messages were delivered with poignance through the development of the characters, not words, which is a huge achievement in it's own right.The voice actors also did a spectacular job in capturing their animated counterparts. Amy Poehler was delightful to listen to as Joy, while Phyllis Smith stole the show with her down-beat but undeniably wonderful performance as Sadness. Speaking of sounds, how about the score ? In a film that is already filled with brisk animation and an inventive script, the score, by the beloved Michael Giacchino still managed to be the stand out of the show, energizing moments of joy, fear, anger and sadness (pardon the pun), and further push the film's climax (Riley reuniting with her parents) into a tearjerking sequence. For all the people who have seen the film, who didn't cry ? How could you not cry ? HOW ?In the end, the film's poignant subject matter about a young girl who has to move away from her hometown, has trouble coping with her new life, and in the end tried to run away even pushed the boundaries of the film's greatness even more (Imagine what would happen if this was helmed by Brian De Palma). The defining original film of the century (evenly matched by Inception), Inside Out sits unopposed on top of The Best Animated Film of The Decade, eclipsing each and every aim on Pixar's checklist. Beautifully crafted, wonderfully written and deeply loved, Inside Out is the equivalent of Citizen Kane in the animated worldPerfect in every single way possible. 100/100.

Despite not being up there with some of Pixar's best works (the "Toy Story" series, "WALL-e," "UP"), this film is still pretty good. The clever ideas and excellent voice-acting (specifically Richard Kind's role as "Bing-Bong," Riley's invisible friend) that Pixar is known for are still there; the only thing that knocks it down a peg for me is that while the concept is another grand idea from the filmmakers (as is the main message of the film, how we inevitably change as people as we grow up), ironically the story itself feels kind of small and isolated. I would have liked to see more of how Riley and the rest of her life was affected by what was going on internally with her emotions and less of a focus on the adventure of Joy (Amy Poehler) and Sadness (Phyllis Smith) trying to get back to "headquarters." As an additional note, Michael Giacchino delivers yet another incredible score for the film.

My love of Pixar is long-held and borderline uncomfortable for people that hear me talk about. Inside Out continues the trend (or is it a tradition at this point?) of thoughtful, intelligent, hilarious, breathtakingly emotional filmmaking that manages to both push the boundaries of the genre while still existing comfortably inside of them. If you can't find something to like here, there is something deeply and profoundly wrong with you.

Pixar was once a film company known for bringing entertainment, comedy and emotion into an innovating concept. Yet many fans consider post Toy Story 3 films to be the dark age of Pixar. However not only does this film break Pixar's losing streak but it shines alongside the other greatest films they have made. And ironically, they do it with a cast of 1 dimensional characters. How? The audience knows that it's the concept of the Emotions to have only one personality so it never feels stale or out of place. The parallel stories match perfectly and the fictional logic behind the inner workings of the mind are so possible that it makes anyone think that this fantasy world really does exist in all of us.

Wow.... a 5* film? I very, very rarely give 5 stars, but I felt it really was that good! It was moving, funny, uncomfortable, joyful and sad. I have to commend the great voice acting, crisp sound, excellent animation, and a really original idea paced perfectly.At last Pixar have moved away from some of their pointless sequels and have created a work of genius. This is a shoe-in for the animated film Oscar, and dare I say it, it deserves to be nominated for Best Film.This was an awesome fantastical ride from start to finish.The film explores (amongst other things) abstract thought, the complexity of memory (e.g. how you can at one moment remember the most inane things, but can lose hold of your dearest core memories), depression, joy, and the human subconscious.Pete Docter was the man behind Up, and Monsters Inc, and I think he's matched and just about beaten both of them here (although don't get me wrong, both of those films are amazing!).Usually there are pop culture references throughout Pixar films, but here they were scarce, and it worked. When they were used, it was to good effect ("opinions and facts - they look so similar!"). By keeping the "human" characters simple (and in places quite stereotypical) it allowed me to really focus on the fantastical characters who carry the real plot, and empathise with the humans.This is great for kids and adults alike, but unlike other Pixar films where it is just excellent, this worked on completely different levels for different people. I am pretty sure, that adults, teens, kids, singles, and couples would all get something different and equally beneficial from the film. I would probably say being a parent gave it a whole new level for me as well - I'd be surprised if any parent didn't appreciate this film.Reflecting on the story now, I wonder if the adventure was causing the protagonist Riley to act the way she did, or was what she was doing causing the story with Joy, Sadness, Rage, Disgust and Fear to occur? The great thing is that both directions work equally well. The former is a great rollercoaster ride like most Pixar films, and the latter is a psychologically moving drama. I will be very surprised if you can make it through this film without almost shedding a tear at least once!At its most abstract, it reminded me of Fantasia, and at its deepest it would probably make Freud smile.For me, it's one of the best depictions of depression put to film. Loads of films still show people crying lots and just being "very sad" when they are 'depressed'. But here it was the absence of joy and sadness that really showed depression. Watching a child with an absence of joy and sadness, watching her personality crumble and be replaced with an emptiness that only fear, disgust and anger could fill, was rather heart-rending. What made it genius is that it was still exceptionally funny in places, and stay a really fun film. It never stopped being a film that kids would enjoy and get a lot from, and stayed true to being a film that was at heart discussing the importance of sadness in your life. It had unsentimental morals that really aren't common in American films for children. I really liked that it treated it's young audience as if they had brains, and that they were not just there for some yawn cartoony ride with a pointless dance off at the end (cue latter Shreks, Hotel Transylvania, A.N. Other CGI Animation, etc).There is a lot of simplicity in the film too (e.g. humans don't just have 5 emotions, and the parent's brains were very stereotypical), but I found that a clever way to direct the audience to give the fantasy it's full attention and not be distracted by side stories.It's not at all a departure from other Pixar fare, but I felt it was doing much more than just tell a story and that pushed it into the "favourite" category.Some people may feel that it's too ambitious, and didn't really hit its mark, but I just feel that that may be because there was a LOT to get out of this in one sitting. Not only will I have to (and want to) watch this again, but I am pretty sure I will pick up something new every time. For example, it was really interesting to see that the mum's head was captained by Sadness, not because she was sad, but because she is comfortable with having sadness in her life. Everything put to screen seems to have a meaning - from the islands, to the deep memory, to the disintegrating memories (startlingly adult), to the subconscious, to the imagination, to Bing Bong (who for me was the unsung star in the whole film).It's a drama, a comedy, a road movie, a buddy movie, a coming of age story, and of course a brilliant animation. It's all so surprisingly smart!Best animation of the year? Maybe best film of the year. I can see this becoming a favourite fun film at kids birthday parties and at the same time being discussed in classrooms.

Inside Out was an unexpected and completely captivating movie-going experience. I truly loved every minute of it. Even 'Lava', the beautiful short film that premiered before Inside Out itself. The movie tells you the story of Riley and her internal emotional struggles when her family is forced to move across the country. The way that the filmmakers portrayed the emotions was unlike anything I had ever seen. In particular scenes, the audience was watching Riley, or her parents think through things just as I normally would. You move from fear of something, to anger, and onto sadness. You ride the waves of the emotions, but once those emotions were given a personality and a character all their own I found a much deeper level to how we think about our emotions. Imagine if your sadness that you feel every day had a personality. Had emotions of her own. Was a complex and unique person just like us, with motivations and feelings. It gave purpose to Joy's actions be them just or misguided. It gave meaning to the relationship between Joy and Sadness, or Anger and Fear. It is a beautiful movie that truly moved me. One of the best I've seen this year and quite possibly the best Pixar has ever made.

I actually saw this movie several weeks ago. I just haven't been able to come up with a lot of in depth things to say about it; at least not enthusiastically. This seems to happen to me a couple of times a year. A highly anticipated movie starts generating a lot of buzz with critical acclaim and with great word of mouth which gets me pumped to see it. I then see it; I like it, but don't love it. Skyfall, Captain America 2, Lego Movie, and now Inside Out.I've never been a die-hard Pixar fan. I do really like most of their stuff, but they've clearly seen better days. It seems since Toy Story 3, Pixar has been in a slump. We got a sequel nobody wanted (Cars 2), a prequel nobody wanted (Monsters University), and a creatively bankrupt bait n' switch (Brave). Don't get me wrong, Inside Out is a good solid movie that has a lot going for it and it is a step in the right direction for Pixar.Inside Out's premise is very intriguing. A young girl named Riley whose emotions are manifested within her mind as real characters: Joy, Sadness, Fear, Anger, and Disgust. These characters collectively represent Riley as a person as they each play a role in her life and upbringing. As she gets older and goes through life-changing situations, her emotions become conflicted and at odds with each other. This is easily the deepest, most complex movie Pixar has ever conceived. Although not at all an ORIGINAL concept, it is still very creative and thought provoking. Everything going on in the mind is visually represented here. Core memories, the Train of Thought, memory dumps and many many others. It's very clear really smart people worked on this story and they go straight for the jugular on its emotional impact. This is a movie everybody can relate to and I will admit, I got a bit teary-eyed toward the end during a final moment between Riley and her parents.So why aren't I over the moon about this movie? It's very creative, beautifully animated, and is universally relatable. For me, Inside Out is so deep, so mature, so... emotional that it often forgets to have fun. Oh, there are fun moments, but they are completely drowned out by the heaviness of Riley's increasingly chaotic inner thoughts. I can't remember the last time I've seen so much crying in a movie. It just wasn't very pleasant to watch at times because the movie rarely ever takes a break to lighten up the mood which can make it seem dull at times. When I watch a Pixar film, I expect to be entertained as well as emotionally moved and Inside Out just didn't do enough entertaining for me to fully love it.Inside Out is a respectable step in the right direction for Pixar, but I still don't think they're fully "back" yet. I did enjoy it and I'm sure most others will too.

Pete Docter, director and brain behind both these films, I hate you.

Just got back from my 3rd viewing of Inside Out, and I have seen portions in the theater numerous more times. Rating: Flawless I absolutely adore this film, definitely the best of the year for me and I cannot think of another movie I have enjoyed this much in some time. This film captivates you from the moment it starts rolling and never misses a beat. The fantastic and emotional journey you take along the way with the complex character culminates in a heartwarming climax. The actors that bring the voices to life are perfect for the roles that they play, even if some of them are type-casted. The leads of Amy Poehler as Joy and Phyllis Smith as Sadness are amazing, and supported by everyone else as well. My personal favorite is Bill Hader as Fear, since he is the main source of humor which we know he does wonderfully. The concept is refreshingly creative and presented in a beautiful artistic manner. Once the movie starts rolling with the different emotions and how the brain saves memories you latch on and become invested. As the film continues to build on its concepts you get to enjoy more complex aspects and move into other people's emotions, but it never feels like a gimmick. The last part that I have to mention is the moving score by Michael Giacchino. The piano in the beginning and every time that is presented afterwards gives you the fuzzies. This is one of the best animated films made to date, I will own it and love it for all time.

I went with my family to see Inside Out today and I really think we must have watched a different film to everyone else. We don't go to the cinema that often as it's difficult enough to find a film that will suit both my 4 year old daughter and 8 year old son, who have understandably pretty opposite tastes in films. None the less, based on trailers and good reviews we had high hopes for Inside Out. We were very disappointed. I think I've seen it described as"poignant and joyful" which I will now take to read as dismal and depressing with the odd funny moment. From a promising start it took us on a slow plod of a journey into depression to a bizarrely rushed upbeat ending. Don't get me wrong, it's not a bad film, it could just have been a lot better (or at least a lot more funny and a lot less depressing). The bits with the banter between the different emotions were very good, and had the film focused more on those and less on the increasingly tedious attempts of Joy and Sadness to get back to HQ it would have been a far better film. By the umpteenth obstacle that got cast in their path I just wanted the film to end - this was not helped by my four year old spending most of the film curled up on my lap asking when the nasty film was going to end. In her own words she found it too sad, too scary and too boring. It is probably not the best Pixar film to take very young children to. So on to my eight year old. His summary - "Ok but dull". Not a real winner there either. I don't think it's one we will be buying on DVD.

I'm not a big fan of animated fun-for-the-whole-family movies. Usually, that means they are only fun for the youngest age bracket of movie watchers and the rest of us are just waiting for it to be over. Pixar is my exception to this rule. Toy Story is one of my favorite movie trilogies. I laughed out loud at Finding Nemo, Up, Monsters Inc, and so on. Not everything they have done is gold, I admit. After a few that were okay at best, I was starting to worry that the glory days of pixar were behind us. Well, Inside Out was my confirmation that they still know how to get the job done. Not only was the inside of a young girl's mind the perfect setting for a Pixar movie, it was done exactly how it should be. It was funny and clever from start to finish, and at the same time, it was a very honest and touching perspective on growing up. The scene towards the end when everything is put in perspective is perfect, and I have the feeling it's going to stick with me for a long time. Thanks, Pixar. Let's never fight again.

I finally went to a viewing to see what all the hype for this movie was about, and BOY what an emotional ride it was!! Disney/Pixar's latest animation feature film showcases the journey that "emotions" living inside a little girl's mind embark on as the girl's family copes with a big transition in life. I have to say the pacing for this film was so impeccable from beginning to end, I couldn't find a single scene that felt like it was stalling or drifting away from the storytelling; the humorous moments were spot-on, while almost all of the emotional moments were so strong, they brought me to tears (and FYI it's been a very, very long while since the last time a movie made me cry this much). The only bit of complaint I have is that they actually used the juiciest bit of the entire movie in the trailer for the film (which BTW I'm pretty sure most of us have already seen a million times); I wish they had included even more of the firing-back-and-forth between each of the characters' emotions. And oh, did I mention that the graphics in this film looked fantastic? As with most Pixar films, people may think they're just for kids. But if you look more closely, you'll find that a lot of the underlying messages can also be applied to adult situations as well; especially with this movie, I think many grown-up people (including me) will find something in it that they can relate to. This film is magical, the way Disney/Pixar films are meant to be. For me, it replaces Wall-E as my favorite Pixar film of all time. A noteworthy mention also goes to the animated short that plays before the actual film itself titled "Lava"; despite the fact that it depicts singing volcanoes, it also boasts a tearjerking storyline that rivals that of the feature film itself, and deserves to be seen and cherished on its own. I'm boldly predicting at this point that both "Lava" and "Inside Out" will go on to win Best Animated Short and Best Animation, respectively, at the Oscars next year. Hiro's Score: 5/5

Funny and heartwarming "Inside Out" showcases Pixar at its best with witty dialogue and gorgeous animation. Amy Poehler is as lovable as ever as Joy and Phyllis Smith acts the perfect foil as Sadness. The rest of the emotion crew, including Fear (Bill Hader), Anger (Lewis Black), and Disgust (Mindy Kaling), are equally hilarious. Richard Kind as Bing Bong the Imaginary Friend, however, may take the prize as the standout character with his wonderfully absurd and heartfelt antics. The film's plot suffers a bit from predictability, but is held up in the end by those trademark Pixar "feels". Overall, a great trip to the movies (especially if you can avoid the kiddies).

A fresh, original and much needed revival for Pixar. Inside Out conveys it's message in a fun, ingenious, and ultimately touching way. It's teaches people that it's ok to be emotional once in a while, and that your emotions are here to help you. With almost unanimous praise for this masterpiece of a film, I say to the great Mr Docter, that you would be crazy not to bless this film (and Up) with a sequel. Some young children won't grasp some of the concepts portrayed in this film, but that's ok, because Inside Out is a film that anyone, no matter how old, can relate to and enjoy.

Absolute Brilliance. Inside Out provides profound lessons for both kids and adults on the importance of sadness and how it can be a powerful tool to gaining healing and peace. I cried during this movie, I cried. It was powerful and moving and an excellent addition to the wonderful Pixar library. A must see film of 2015.
I love this movie! It's one of the best I've seen so far besides The Incredibles and Toy Story 3. I suggest watching this movie any old day with family and friends.
Deeper, more insightful and must been seen by anyone over ten.
One of the best family films that pixar has created since Finding Nemo.

Inside Out is one of the most original, clever and laugh out loud films I have seen in a long time. The film explores the emotions of a young girl (Riley) dealing with a tough change in her life; these emotions are portrayed in the form of 5 diverse and very humorous characters. I can imagine that younger viewers will get the most 'Joy' from seeing these unique colourful characters fight over control of Riley's behaviours. As an older viewer I was impressed with how the film explores the inner workings of the mind including aspects such as the 'train of thought', 'imagination land' and how memories are stored and portrayed. With all the complexities in the human mind, Pixar has still managed to make a simple yet clever animation that keeps you smiling throughout and makes you think about the emotions that take control in your own mind. This heartfelt film concludes that you can't have joy without a little sadness and that all the different emotions work together to make us who we are. One of the best Pixar films to date is sure to make you laugh throughout and have you exploring the inner workings of your own mind.
"Come on Joy, I've got feeling about this one."OMG Bing Bong...And who the hell is Bing Bong? Did I forgot somebody who was so important to me in the garbage mountain?

Riley, 11, a girl with an astonishingly limited range of emotions (joy, fear, sadness and anger) has to endure the terrible hardship of relocating to San Francisco from Minnesota and loses her shit. And then (of course) finds it again - by rehabilitating sadness because sometimes, Sadness Can Be Good. Sentimental skit, no that's not a typo, based on the premise that Joy, and her handmaiden happiness, constitute the fundamental human condition. This is of course a truth we hold to be self-evident, and therefore cannot be disproved - like by actual evidence. Best moment comes at the end (no, not for that reason) when the conceit that humans are driven by four simple emotions operating a console that becomes upgraded as we grow up (i.e, the apps get cleverer but the operator doesn't), is extended to other characters, including (best of all) a street cat (no, not that sort, an actual cat).
Too complex for kids and the character design is veeery lazy, Forgettable.
Loved that movie. I went to see it with my 4,5yo and he told me that he haven't seen such a good movie in a while. Guess he was right!

But, for me, the journey of Joy and Sadness was much too long, and a bit boring. I started eagerly hoping we'd "get back to headquarters" - maybe even more than the characters were! Still, it's a fun, family movie and the end, with all the peeks into various brains, was great!p.s. - The short film before, "Lava", was so wonderful! Flat out wonderful!

This movie was one of the best movies I've EVER seen Disney Pixar create. I loved the concept of all the emotions interacting and how Sadness and Joy go on this amazing adventure. 100% from me. I hope there's a sequel!

Pixar's latest is a masterpiece! It is also an amazingly thoughtful and original idea, full of wit and imagination.  Eleven year old Riley and her family leave the Mid-west for a new start in San Francisco and things don't go as planned. This setup is bizarrely the SETTING rather than the characters in this film. The main protagonists are Riley's emotions, led by Joy (Amy Poehler) whose influence has been the main one in young Riley's life so far. After all, who doesn't want to be full of joy? However, Sadness, Anger, Fear and Disgust all start to play their part as Riley deals with the challenges of a new and unfamiliar environment, family friction, new school and growing from young childhood to those awkward teen years.I must admit, I was very unsure whether this pretty unusual premise would work. This idea that we all NEED sadness and anger to appreciate the good times, that we are all a mixture of emotions, and that different ones control us at different times is rather deep. Critics adore it, I do wonder whether children are quite as enchanted, or whether they are confused or wishing for more crashes and bangs!However, despite the philosophical thread running through the film, there is plenty of fun to be had. Amy Poehler is perfect as the chirpy Joy, trying to find a way to get back in control. The script is full of quick wit and throwaway jokes - a whole run of hilarious looks into other brains at the end was brilliant, particularly the cat! I also loved the brief visits to Riley's mum and dad's brains too.So innovative and thought provoking, this is a mini masterpiece!

perhaps the best thing about inside out is that is answers all the confusing questions kids ask themselves as they grow up , and tells them that it is ok to be sad , and that sadness is an important part of life

So... You want to watch Inside Out? Let me answer that question for you - no you don't. Think of it as a culmination of all the worst films you've already watched with a sprinkling of your worst fears. I'm talking clowns for all you party virgins out there. I don't think I could possibly put into words how terrible this film is. I spent about half of the film with my fist in my mouth trying to prevent myself from either screaming at the screen or just laughing tears of despair and frustration. Sadness (an extremely sad, depressed emotion living in the pits of Riley's brain) is probably the most unfortunate character one could ever have the misfortune to turn their nose up to. Think of her as the offspring of the annoying little kid from UP who everyone seems to pity because of his lack of a brain or any form of common sense and Jack Frost from Rise of the Guardians - or, even better, the disastrous result of a cruel sexual experiment between Justin Bieber and Susan Boyle. And that's putting it lightly.I can only begin to imagine the sheer temptation to throw her over the edge and into that pit of forgotten memories. How Joy managed to refrain from doing so I cannot comprehend.I would like to end this review by saying NO. Just NO. This film is one big disappointment and left me feeling, quite frankly, like a deflated walrus.Do not put yourself through an hour and 40 minutes of this. It's not worth the �7.70 you spent on it.

Well only one word came out of this movie for me. Mental Health. Well two. hahaah. I found the movie very heartwarming. The plot very confusing, but basically all over the place. I said to a staff member who has seen the movie, whom I know well, that you'd have to have a very good mental health ie not depressed etc., etc., You'd have to be very mentally strong. A girl Riley(Dias) moves from Minnesota to San Francisco. However her emotions are played upon. Emotions being Joy(Poehler), Sadness(Smith), Fear(Hader) Disgust(Kaling) and Anger(Black). Sadness keeps interfering with the Memories and the Core memories. And hence Joy and Sadness somehow get out of teh HQ, so they meet up with Bing Bong(Kind) and have many an adventures. So overall, not the best movie from PIxar. However I can sense a sequiel thou. So lets hope that'll be better. hahah

This beautiful new Disney-Pixar animation passed the six laugh (and the six tears!) test easily. It's a thought-provoking, life-examining film that will stay with you for days afterwards. My friends and I enjoyed talking through the five core emotional drives (Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear and Disgust) and whether they do a sufficient job in summing up the human experience. I personally found the sections of the film which were OUT more compelling than those that were INSIDE, though probably 80% of the movie is the latter. I was deeply moved by 11-year-old Riley's public grief at losing her childhood home and centre of emotional gravity, and the much-trailered dinner table family interaction is hilarious. The vast bulk of the film is set inside Riley's head and it becomes a somewhat agonised quest-romp to get two of the key emotions back to the HQ and so to restore Riley's full personality. It's a fantastic gem of a movie - I just would have enjoyed it even more if there had been more outer world/inner world interaction, more actual real world plot, and more insights into the heads of other characters. I saw it with a group of people with ages ranging from 15-50, so would be intrigued to see it again with littl'uns to watch their joy, anger, disgust, fear and sadness in watching this...

I didn't think that this movie lived up to the 98 percent score and critical acclaim that it got. While it was a fun and fresh story by Disney, it wasn't Frozen, Toy Story or one of the other Disney heavyweights. A definite renter especially for those with children, but I'd temper expectations a bit.

Enthralling, shattering, an amazing journey... if you're an adult. There is no denying that Inside Out was the most intellectually stimulating Pixar project right from its trailers. The idea was simply brilliant and no other animated movie made me this excited in recent times. Finally we got a movie which was little of a mixed bag but with loads to charm and ingenuity. The portrayal of different emotions, variations and properties of memories and how they change once we grow up and our personalities set in were portrayed beautifully. As ever, Pixar still stands as a company which illustrates human emotions like no one else. A must watch for kids and adults alike, Inside Out is bound to win accolades and the best animated movie of this year so far.

This may well go down as one of Pixars better movies in a list of movies that are all pretty good. This film follows a little girl named Riley and the emotions that control her moods and its the emotions that really make this movie. Joy, Anger, Fear, Disgust and Sadness make up the team but as Riley moves home with her parents the once joyful kid hits a bumpy path as Joy and Sadness find themselves outside of HQ leaving Anger, Fear and Disgust in charge which means they really need to find their way back. It was an awesome made movie and although aimed at kids is still an awesome watch for adults too

Oh man. This movie really brought me to tears and a whole kaleidoscope of emotions by the end. I don't care that it's not perfect in certain respects. This film is now so close to my heart that it transcends the need for reviews anymore.
